reviewText: Like chocolates and potato chips, only one will not do.  One must watch them all--all the series and the collections.  Suchet and associates are addictive.  I just wish there was a more orderly way of assembling the movies and series episodes.  I have duplicates.  But, oh well, I just give them to friends and hope they will get hooked too.  Perhaps we'll keep Suchet returning to this role which he has mastered.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This collection as described above is first 4 feature length shown in 2001 by A&E after London Weekend Television (and PBS for us here in the US) dropped the series of mixed hour 2 hour (2 part 1 hour each actually) shows.  This same set was released by A&E as a 4 pack after the 4th, Evil Under The Sun was released separately. Most likely, A&E like they did with Hornblower is just reissuing the set in thin cases.  Since the entire collection that A&E showed are still being offered as the Definitive Collection (which I also think is in thin cases) there is no need for the double dip.  Bad enough that Acorn is reissuing the older series which they did best in with the 2 "classic collections" 1 for the hour lengths, and 1 for the 2 hour lengths.  The only reason they are doing it because they (Acorn) are releasing the newest feature lengths which were released in a 4 pack in England (I got that one) and are being issued only 2 at a time here now and they want to color code those new sets with their release of the older series.  I have also seen on Amazon UK, a mega set featuring all the LWT/PBS (the ones on Acorn here) AND all the A&E released here ones in 1 set, INCLUDING THE $ NEWBIES.  Want my advice folks, if you haven't done anything yet, buy THAT set (and of course a region free player) or at the worst, buy the Acorn released "Classic Collections" 1 and 2 (while they are still available), the A&E Definitive Collection, and the ITV (in England) copy of the newbies (which for all 4 is cheaper than the 2fer being released by Acorn now), and of course the region free player for the latter.
summary: 5 stars for content, 1 for beating a dead horse

reviewText: Here's a nice murder mysteries collection of Agatha Christie's Hercule Poirot Series. It's an easy going and amusing set of private investigator tales told in the "Who Did it?" manner where the clues are revealed and it's up to the viewer, along with super-sleuth Hercule Poirot to come up with the answer. Can you beat him? I doubt it, but it's fun trying.Hercule Poirot is masterfully played by David Suchet as a quaint, somewhat irritating little twerp who always seems to be at the right place for some evil deed, in these cases murder, to happen. It's easy to recognize Poirot. He's a squat, robust little fellow who is always overdressed for the occasion. He sports a little black mustache which looks like a piece of shiny black plastic stuck to his upper lip. His manners are impeccable and his surroundings are always in the highest taste. His criminals must rank among the most civil of any movie series. Violence is all but absent. The supporting cast is excellent and the individual episodes are fun to watch. It's genuinely a throwback to kinder, gentler times.These movies take place in the thirties, so one of the fun things to watch for are the magnificently restored automobiles of that era. Whoever has charge of that part of the programing has come up with some real jewels! If you're at all interested in old automobiles, maintain a close watch. My bet is you can't identify even half of the brands shown, but it's very interesting trying and I wish there was a list to let you know if you were right or wrong.A typical Poirot episode begins with an introduction placing Poirot in a particular setting for a particular reason. Then a murder happens and Poirot begs off being a part of the investigation, but it never works. Then the clues start to fall here and there. Beware. Each episode has scattered misleading clues and it's easy to let your mind go astray. After a considerable amount of puzzlement, a meeting takes place in which all of the suspects gather and Poirot goes over the clues and his interpretation of them. Did you follow the movie closely? Do you have your clues right? Are you as good as Poirot at solving mysteries? I'd guess not. There are always surprises, but it's an enjoyable game.In this particular set of mysteries, I thought "The Murder of Roger Ackroyd" and "Lord Edgware Dies" were the two best episodes by a slight margin. "Murder in Mesopotamia" and Evil under the Sun" fell slightly behind in my personal ranking. Your ranking may well differ. What you have here is an enjoyable set of really old-fashioned movies. Relax and enjoy.Gary Peterson
summary: Alright, Who Did It? Enjoyable And Amusing Movies.
